title: chore: release integration testing framework
body: We haven't updated this for a while.

title: feat: simplify gas tracking stack
body:
Switch from taking/restoring the gas tracker, to a smarter gas tracker that internally keeps a gas limit stack.

I asked for the implementation I'm now replacing to save some allocations and avoid some error cases. In hindsight, that was a mistake.

I'm changing this now because I'd otherwise need to create a separate "long lived" gas tracking structure.

title: feat: normalize transaction signatures
body:
This normalizes the logic between different transaction systems in the FVM.

Pre-factor for https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/pull/1521

title: feat: `CarReader::read_into()`
body:
# Summary

Provide a way for devs to perform actions/checks on car data before loading it into the store

# Why

resolves #1522 

# What

- Move private fn `load_car_inner` to `CarReader::read_into()`
- `load_car` and `load_car_unchecked` construct their own car readers and call `read_into`
- Add file test using CarReader directly

title: Release ipld_encoding 0.3.3, FVM 3.0.0-alpha.21
body: As in the title.

title: fix: expose the effective gas premium
body:
We previously exposed the specified gas premium, but that's not all that useful. The user pays the _effective_ gas premium, which is capped at `feecap - basefee`. I.e., the user never pays more than the fee cap.

Unfortunately, this needs to be behind a feature flag on hyperspace until the c.3 upgrade.

fixes #1471

title: fix: fix build when testing isn't enabled
body: This appears to be a casualty of rust's feature unification. We should have caught this in CI, but feature unification ensured that this feature got _enabled_, so we didn't.

title: FVM: Use CBOR instead of DAG_CBOR for message params
body: Fixes #1001

title: chore: update & audit deps
body:
We don't want to update any of the others, so this should close the issue. It was faster to do it than to talk about it.

fixes #1450

title: FVM: Machine: Put the Empty Array CID on creation, if missing
body:
Fixes #1359 

I wanted to put this in a separate method (something like `put_empties_in_blockstore()`, because we'll probably want to expand this to include things like empty maps, but wasn't sure how to specify the type for the blockstore param (and didn't want to fight Rust). Happy to make that change if we think it's better (and @Stebalien shows me how to do it) :P

title: feat: use a struct for network versions
body: The enum means we'd need to extend this for every network version added. We still have constants for every _named_ network version.

title: add feature to support hyperspace version lineages.
body:
We expect to upgrade Hyperspace in ways that do not require changes to ref-fvm. Instead of modelling every network version independently, we absorb future network versions into a general enum value "NetworkVersion::VNNOnwards".

Future upgrades involving ref-fvm changes will motivate creating new physical network versions.

title: feat: cache new addresses
body:
When we register a new address (e.g., when auto-creating an actor on first send), cache it.

This will be important for gas tracking.

title: fix: correctly return out of gas errors when instantiating
body:
We were implicitly converting them to "anyhow" errors, then treating them as fatal.

fixes #1486

title: chore: release fvm v2.2.0
body: Mostly updates wasmtime to 2.0.2.

title: release: fvm
body: (really this time)

title: chore: release fvm, kamt, amt
body: I'm skipping the HAMT because that has some API changes and no new features.

title: v2: deps: Update wasmtime to v2.0.2
deps: Update wasmtime to v2.0.2
body:
I'm not entirely sure if we'll be able to update beyond 2.0.2 on time without at least some fixes/features in wasmtime due to https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/pull/1412#pullrequestreview-1247553574.

This is likely the second best thing we can do.

title: Refactor: Move Response from SDK to shared
body: As in the title

title: feat: add a basic block size limit
body:
Chosen to be 1MiB as that should be about 10x larger than anything in-use today.

fixes https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/1278

title: [v2] Fix log initialisation to set max level, else all messages are discarded
body:
Well, this took a very long time to discover.

This is already fixed on master, but built-in actors are still targeting v2.

Note that even after this change I _still_ can't get logs to produce syscalls when using the v2 SDK, but I can if I install my own logger, which is good enough for now.

Related: #1397

title: SDK: refactor: exit takes Option<IpldBlock>
body: As in the title.

title: feat: adjust memory retention fee
body:
TL;DR: This reduces read/write costs by 0.4.

The point of this fee is to charge at _least_ 10gas/byte. So that's what we now do. Instead of charging an additional fee, we:

1. Compute the actual per-byte "compute" fees.
2. Compute the minimum memory retention fee.
3. Apply a memory retention surcharge up to the minimum memory retention fee.

This seems complex, but the effect is simple: We're now charging 0.4 gas less per byte for reads and writes. I could have just reduced the memory retention cost by 0.4, but the new logic more accurately reflects our intentions with this fee.

title: feat: change the recursive call limit to 1024
body:
This was always supposed to be 1024, but became 1025 due to a bug in the implementation (before network launch). We're taking this opportunity to fix this long-standing bug as we change other system limits to bring them in-line with other VMs like the EVM.

(i.e., this will require a one-line comment in the FIP, so we might as well do it right now).

title: Release SDK 3.0.0-alpha.20
body: As in the title.

title: SDK: refactor: send should only return exit code and return data
body: #1366 , but on master

title: Add custom Debug impl for `IpldBlock` formatting to use hex
Release SDK 2.2.0
body: Releases #1366

title: [v2] Add a Log execution event, created with the log syscall
body:
I am attempting to improve instrumentation to support analysis of gas charges across spans of code. See #1397.

This PR adds a `Log` execution event to the trace format. A log event is recorded when the `log` syscall is invoked. The log event carries a single `String` message.

A string is the most basic payload to carry here, so I think the right place to start. Some structure may be encoded into strings (for subsequent offline analysis). We could consider adding some kind of key/value pair metadata, but I suggest we defer until observed usage justifies it.

Note that the GasCharge event's `name` is a `Cow<'static, str>`. I presume this is because the same literal name is expected to be used frequently and this type will lead to meaningful optimisation. I'm not sure that that's appropriate for the `Log` event, if it would rule out dynamically constructed messages.

This PR is against the `release/v2` branch, because I am analysing the built-in actors that are not yet using fvm v3. I intend to forward-port it when stable.

title: remove the explicit extern cost & cleanups
body:
We're slowly re-pricing these syscalls so we no longer need an explicit "extern" cost.

This is a code change and doesn't affect gas values.

title: feat: finalize write costs
body:
From #1264, we've learned that the compute gas for flushing state is
approximately 171963 per block.

I've:

1. Rounded this up to 172k (our measurements aren't that accurate).
2. Added a new "100 byte" (`100 * 1300 = 130k` gas) cost to the storage fee to cover per-block metadata and overhead.

This comes out to ~52k _less_ gas/block than the current per-block fee of 353640. However, when taking all costs into account (hashing, syscall overhead, allocations, memcpy, etc.) we're about even with pre-FVM gas fees for blocks less than 1KiB.

I'm _not_ charging per-byte for compute on flush because we're already charging 1300gas/byte in storage fees. This vastly exceed the per-byte compute cost, a couple of memory copies and allocations that would work out to be < 5gas/byte.

fixes #1264

title: fix: return NotFound from balance_of
body:
The second half of #949. Found by @ZenGround0 in #1378

fixes #1378

title: chore: migrate to `rust-toolchain.toml`
body:
Changes:
- migrate to `rust-toolchain.toml` which is capable of specifying required`components` and `targets` so that contributors won't need to install them manually
- cleanup CI yaml accordingly

title: feat: rewrite the state snapshot system to have O(1) lookups
body:
Instead of keeping true state "layers", we now keep an undo history.

1. When opening a new transaction, we record the current undo history height for both the resolve and state cache.
2. On abort, we walk the undo history backwards, undoing any changes.

This is `O(changes)` on revert, but that's fine. The cost of a potential revert can be charged when the change is made in the first place.

This is strictly better than the current situation where we spend `O(changes)` on every commit, which turns into `O(changes * call_depth)`.

Specifically:

1. Commits are O(1).
2. Actor Insertions/Deletions are O(1).
3. Actor address/state are O(1).
4. Reverts are O(N) in the amount of history being reverted.

I've also removed the `StateSnapshots` abstraction as it was just getting in the way.

fixes #1343

title: Restrict create_actor to the InitActor as caller
body: Closes https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/1186

title: test: events: add a test case for out-of-gas.
body: Also moves the setup logic to a helper method.

title: SDK: refactor: send should only return exit code and return data
body:
More work towards #987 

`Send` now returns a `Response` comprising of an exitcode and an optional IpldBlock return.

title: KAMT: fix serialization/deserialization
body:
We were using the "struct" (json-like) representation instead of the tuple representation, and we were encoding the extension as a list of bytes (numbers) instead of as a byte-string.

This version:

1. Simplifies the serialization/deserialization logic. We had all the IPLD stuff to because we didn't have a tag. Now that we have a tag, we can use CBOR's built-in support for it.
2. Encodes links as a single tuple of CID, length, and pointer.

Unfortunately, it I couldn't find a simple way to _entirely_ rely on the deriving logic, but I've made it do most of the work.

I'm inlining the extension into the link to save a byte in the encoding.

fixes #1356

title: Small KAMT improvements
body:
This patch contains two small KAMT improvements that make it easier to understand and reason about.

(prep work for #1356)

title: Executor: Always transform embryo to eth_account if executing message
feat: fix block read charges
body:
This change makes the block "read" charge more accurate.

It also moves all the "extern" charges to the "other" gas field so we can keep benchmarking locally. In the future, we'll likely want four fields to split this into multiple fields, but not now.

part of #1264

title: feat: refactor memory limits and apply to tables
body:
Motivation:

1. Explicitly limit table memory. We shouldn't be growing tables, but it's nice to have this check in place.
2. Pave the way for explicitly limiting block memory. We still need to _benchmark_ maximum blockstore memory before we can actually enable a limit, but I'd like to get _a_ limit into M2.1 if possible (instead of relying on gas).

Changes:

First, this refactors memory limits to remove the per-instance limits from the limiter itself (this is enforced by wasmtime) and instead track a global/shared "memory" limit. It then applies this to tables.

Second, this patch removes wasmtime interfaces from the limiter, instead implementing a wrapper to adapt to wasmtime's expected interface. I generally try to avoid exposing wasmtime types.

Finally, this fixes a small bug in the test limiter's minimum memory tracking (to correctly track the minimum non-zero amount allocated by any instance). This patch also tracks the minimum/maximum _table_ sizes.

title: fix: remove support for non-key addresses from verify_signature
body:
This change doesn't require a FIP because the builtin actors won't call this syscall with anything but a key address.

fixes #1228

body: Ideally we'd have a constant somewhere for this, but we'll need to think a bit more about the structure here.

title: Explicit gas charges for different instruction types (take 2)

We now explicitly charge for individual instructions, and reject unsupported ones.

This doesn't (confirmed with fvm-bench) change the actual _costs_ of any instructions (yet).

title: Split the "read" cache from the "write" cache in the state-tree

This will let us charge the right amount for updating state. Otherwise, we end up making changes to the state-tree even if we only _read_ some actor's state.

title: CallManager: Restrict embryo creation to the EAM's namespace
body: This isn't strictly necessary, since there _shouldn't_ be anything wrong with deploying embryos to other ID namespaces. However, only embryos in the EAM's namespace can be deployed at today, so we might as well restrict this for now and not have to think about it.

title: Remove the Cbor trait and its uses
body:
This "convenience" trait in the shared libraries introduced additional coupling between actors and FVM libraries, e.g. where an actor object that didn't provide the empty `impl Cbor` block would be unusable in some places.

It's not that convenient, since removing it gives a nice net reduction in code.

The built-in actors no longer use this as of https://github.com/filecoin-project/builtin-actors/pull/960

The singletons now generally assert that they've been created by the "system" actor.

body:
This:

- Simplifies the FIP (we can add it to FIP0048 and be done).
- Simplifies the concepts (predictable was nasty).
- Allows us to eventually just assign f4 addresses to everything.

There are three parts to this change:

1. Restore the logic for resolving key addresses when verifying signatures.
2. Mass rename of predictable -> delegated.
3. No longer store f1/f3 in this field.

fixes #1289

I moved this to the call manager then failed to remove this one.

Testing issue is https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/1287. I tried writing a test for this, but failed because I can't call init actor methods from "test" actors due to the API export limits.

title: refactor: update the gas schedule
body:
# Code Changes

1. Remove the old gas schedules. We don't support these releases and we don't need to try to maintain compatibility.
2. Use ScalingCost everywhere to make things simpler.
3. Add clear TODOs for gas prices that need to be figured out.
4. Try to clearly split up operations in a way that should be easier to measure.
5. Rename the "storage gas" field on gas charges to "other gas", and move all charges that aren't charging for _immediate_ computation. This makes benchmarking easier. Includes:
    - Deferred operations (e.g., flush).
    - Memory retention
    - Storage
    
# Syscall Gas Changes

The following changes have been made since M1. This includes reverting some of the changes that are currently on master.

## Signature Validation

- Secp256k1 signature verification has gained a new 10gas/byte cost to reflect the cost of hashing (blake2b).
- BLS signature verification has gained a new 26gas/byte cost to reflect the cost of hashing.

## Hashing

Hashing no longer has a flat cost (was 31355) but has the following costs (per algorithm):

- sha256: 7gas/byte
- blake2b: 10gas/byte
- keccak256: 33gas/byte
- ripemd160: 35gas/byte

For sha256, the "break-even" is ~4.5KiB, for blake2b the break-even is ~3.1KiB. Overall, these changes should result in a gas cost reduction as most things we hash on-chain are tiny.

TODO: sha256 likely assumes hardware support and will need more testing.

## Memory

- Memory copy costs have been reduced from 0.5gas/byte to 0.4gas/byte.
- The "memory retention" cost of 10gas/byte has been split into a 2gas/byte memory _allocation_ cost, and an 8gas/byte memory retention cost. This change does not affect actual gas costs, it just splits the cost into a "compute" cost (allocation) and a non-compute cost (memory retention).

## Storage

Block storage costs have increased by 13.8gas/byte (from 1300gas/byte to 1313.8gas/byte, or 1%):

- PLUS 2 * 2 = 4 gas for an expected 2 allocations (one on write, one on flush).
- PLUS 10gas/byte for hashing.
- MINUS 0.1 * 2 gas/byte for the reduction in memcpy costs.

## Randomness

Randomness now charges for hashing. Specifically, it charges:

1. 1400 for the "extern" call.
2. 10gas/byte of entropy plus 480 gas for hashing the randomness itself.

This is likely still a small under-charge (we're missing some hashing and copying costs), but it brings us closer.

title: OPT-892: Hamt max array width made configurable.
body:
Related to https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/892 

The PR moves the currently constant `MAX_ARRAY_WIDTH` into the `hamt::Config`. 

We realized in https://github.com/filecoin-project/builtin-actors/pull/926 that the `min_data_depth` option added in https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/pull/1088 is only really useful if the size of the `KeyValuePair`s are much larger than the pointers they are replaced with, or when we know for sure that there will be enough items inserted that they will result in a deep HAMT, and when we only need to access a few entries at a time. In these cases we can skip having to read/write an overweight root node every time.

For the EVM this wasn't the case, because the keys are the values are both 32 bytes, which is comparable to a CID. In this case a pointer to a node containing a single value is an overhead. We realized that we can have the best of both worlds by restricting the maximum number of entries in a bucket to one: then it doesn't matter if it's a KV pair or a pointer, but as soon as there would be two KV pairs, they get pushed down. 

The array width was made configurable in the `Kamt`, but probably I don't see why it couldn't be useful in the `Hamt` as well.

title: OPT-915: Amt::flush short circuit if nothing changed.
body:
Closes https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/915

The PR adds a `flushed_cid` to the `Amt` data structure so that we can skip writing to the block store when `flush()` is called if nothing changed since the data was loaded or last flushed. This should save a little gas when `Amt` is used in smart contracts.

title: fix the m2-native feature missing engine getter
body: fix [#1257](https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/1257)

title: fix: avoid default features and disable in CI
body:
1. Avoid cases where we need to specify default features (except opencl in the fvm crate).
2. Disable default features in CI.

This lets us _reliably_ disable OpenCL. Otherwise, we need OpenCL to build, which isn't usually present in CI.

This also removes the "debug" feature from the SDK, because we always enable that anyways.

title: Revert: Remove blake2b hashing which was moved to builtin-actors
body: This only reverts the portion of #804 that touched ipld::encoding. This allows us to ship patch releases off the v2 branch, while still getting the benefit of this in the v3 branch.

title: Release SDK 2.1.0, ipld_encoding 0.2.3
body: @Stebalien / reviewer: please confirm that ipld_encoding can be a patch release (only _adding_ a type), while SDK is a minor release.

title: GAS-1051: Gas time stats and visualization (to master)
body:
Closes https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/1051 , https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/1160 and https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/1147

This is a rebased and cherry-picked version of these PRs:
* https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/pull/1054
* https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/pull/1148
* https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/pull/1192
* https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/pull/1242

See the individual PRs for the description of their content. 

The TL;DR version is that this PR adds:
* Gas time tracing exports to conformance tests with visualization and regressions to check how well the models work on the test vectors. Unfortunately these won't work on master because there aren't test vectors for the latest builtin-actor bundle. The previous experience was also that the data sizes used by these are in a range where the model fit isn't great. 
* A targeted gas calibration contract that we can use to run specific instructions with various inputs we control, to establish the model parameters on a wider domain. 

This PR doesn't modify the prices. That will happen in follow up PRs, focusing on one thing at a time, and using these visualizations and models to see if the new results are reasonable. Ideally we would do these on some canonic environment. 

What would be nice is to have an idea of:
* What should be a representative machine config to run the calibration on?
* Is there a conversion factor we can use to extrapolate IO access time based on the in-memory measurements, based on some existing statistics from Lotus?

body: fixes #1257

#1230

title: Implement MMVP Account Abstraction
body:
- Remove the f4-as-account feature/hack entirely
- The executor checks if sender is an embryo actor
- If so, and the delegated address is in the f410 namespace, an Ethereum Account is deployed there

Note that no signature validation is performed. As with secp/BLS messages, it is the responsibility of the client to validate siggys.

title: feat: add charging for all memory copy/init operations
body:
I'm not actually charging anything right now, but this lets us charge for:

1. Memory copying.
2. Memory "filling" (where I'm treating all memory expansion as "filling").

fixes #1075

title: feat: update instrumentation
body:
We're not yet taking advantage of it, but this uses the new
instrumentation logic.

title: GAS-1160: Convert gas to time on chart.
body:
Applies a transformation from gas to time on the charts, so that we can see directly how the slope of the gas model relates to the observations. 

# Analysis

Caveat: that this is just my laptop.

* `OnBlockCreate`: Overcharging.
* `OnBlockLink`: Massively undercharging.
* `OnBlockOpenPerByte`: Overcharging.
* `OnBlockRead`: Nice fit, but undercharging at the highest sizes.
* `OnRecoverSecpPublicKey`: Massively undercharging.
* `OnVerifySignature`: The intercepts are charged in nicely, but it doesn't scale with the size.
* `OnHashing`: Massively undercharged.

title: refactor: extract the engine from the machine and make it a pool
body:
Now that we're using the pooling allocator in wasmtime, we have to be careful about sharing a single engine between multiple concurrent message executions. Otherwise, we could run out of wasm "instances" and fail execution (e.g., if the user is validating two blocks in parallel).

To handle this, I've:

1. Turned the engine into an "engine pool" where we allocate `concurrency * call_depth` instances.
2. Put the EnginePool inside the Executor.
3. Put the Engine itself inside the CallManager.

That way, we "acquire" an Engine every time we handle a new message, and release the engine when we're done.

Unfortunately, putting the engine on the _machine_ didn't really make sense anymore, because the engine's lifetime is tied to a specific call and returned to the pool afterwards.

We could have acquired the engine for the lifetime of the _Machine_, but I was concerned about deadlocks.

title: chore: release fvm & sdk
body: This is a small change to count "0" gas as actually 0, instead of infinite. At the same time, we now pass u64::MAX for "all gas".

title: fix: use 0 to mean 0, u64::MAX to mean "all the gas"
body: fixes #1235

title: Add simple test for chain_id syscall
Add syscall `nonce` to get nonce/sequence from explicit message
Revert updates to cid/multihash
body:
Unfortunately, updating cid & mutlihash breaks pretty much everything:

- The FFI imports two versions of the FVM which now use two different CID/Multihash versions.
- We have a common blockstore trait that uses CID in the interface.
- This will likely cause hell for builtin actors.

We can un-revert this if we can backport the changes. But we're not updating cid and/or multihash for the foreseeable future.

title: Add Chain ID to `NetworkContext`
body: closes https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/918

title: feat: disable memory_init_cow
body: Otherwise, some Wasm modules will balloon in size when compiled.

title: v2: Change SDK::send's params to take new type IpldBlock
body:
IpldBlock supports multiple codecs, including IPLD_RAW.

Serializing byte vectors will correctly serialize anything that serializes to "raw bytes". However, it _won't_ serialize "byte lists", so `Vec<u8>` and `[u8]` won't work. But that shouldn't be an issue in practice.

Users _should_ serialize to/from `ByteBuf`.

title: GAS-1160: Calibration contract
body:
Closes https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/1160

The PR adds a `testing/calibration` crate with a `fil-gas-calibration-actor` contract that we can use to focus in on individual syscalls and measure the time it takes to execute them with various input sizes. The crate uses the measurements to run a least squares regression to estimate coefficients that could be used to configure the gas price.

I checked in the plots so we can see the how good the model is on these isolated cases. We can repeat the calibration on a standard environment to get prices we can add to the production price list. 

One thing I want to do to validate if this approach works is to take the coefficients as they are and put them in a calibration price list, then use that price list to run the conformance test vectors, and see what the visualizations in https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/pull/1148 look like on the same machine the prices were calibrated for. Ideally they would be more linear with higher R-squared values.

Should:
- [x] `OnHashing`
- [x] `OnBlock*`
- [x] `OnVerifySignature`
- [x] `OnRecoverSecpPublicKey`

Could:
- [ ] `OnComputeUnsealedSectorCid`
- [ ] `OnVerifySeal`
- [ ] `OnVerifyAggregateSeals`
- [ ] `OnVerifyReplicaUpdate`
- [ ] `OnVerifyPost`

Won't:
- `OnVerifyConsensusFault` (using `DummyExterns`)
- `OnGetRandomness` (using `DummyExterns`)
- `wasm_exec` (the test vectors should be okay for this, but what it would really need is opcode level breakdown)
- `wasm_memory_init`: I tweaked it a little so that the time we associate with this takes into account the everything around module instantiation. The current charge depends on the memory size, not the wasm size, though; I have no idea what the instantiation time will actually depend on. In any case the calibration actor is not a good test for this, because there's no variation in size. We should use the test vectors where at least the various built-in actors are used. It's just tricky to say how we could associate the message with the code size from the test runner. It would have to be an explicit lookup of the code based on the recipient. It looks different enough to be put into a followup PR. Alternatively, we could just load a built-in actor bundle, get their addresses, then throw random messages at them - they won't be processed, but that's fine because we'd only measure module instantiation time. Yet another alternative would be to use @Jacarte wasm corpus to get a wide variety of sizes - again with random messages, just measuring instantiation time.

Can't:
- All the new prices added in https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/pull/1139 would need merging this first, then cherry-picking it to be on top of `master`.


# Analysis

## `overall.png`

The overall charts shows how much we spent doing each charge vs how much we charged for it in gas. The slopes and magnitudes vary wildly, which might show relative mispricing in action. The caveat is where we the prices try to incorporate delayed IO costs.

## Per charge

Each chart shows the input size used by the test driver versus the time we spent doing the operation with that input, and the gas that was charged for it. The gas is displayed as a line on the Y2 axis. Looking at this it's easy to spot two things:
* When we charge a constant gas for something where the execution time actually depends on the input size, the line is horizontal.
* When we charge some base cost, but actually the time we spend with 0 input is near zero, then the gas line intercepts the Y axis at a non-zero point, while the time points go at zero. 

It is tempting to compare the slopes of the Gas and the Time points and call it a good fit, however, that's just an illusion, because they are on different Y axes. To meaningfully compare their slopes, we'd have to agree on how much we'd _like_ to charge for a unit of time, e.g. 100 gas per nanosecond, and then _divide_ the gas with that. Then we could display both in terms of nanos, on the same Y axis. 

To see how different these seemingly fitting prices are, look at `overall.png`.

### `OnHashing`

Hashing time is very linear in the size, with the intercept being at virtually 0. However the different hashing algorithms have markedly different slopes, so it would make sense to differentiate the price by hashing type.

### `OnBlockCreate` 

There is a nice linear relationship captured on the chart. However it's exhibits strange behaviour if certain things are changed in the code in that reordering the steps (like going from high to low sizes, or interleaving puts and gets) can introduce a second, cheaper slope. 

If we look closer, up to 100,000 bytes the cheaper slope is still present.

I left it at this version because this had the highest slope and I thought over estimating the cost is a better default. 

### Other `OnBlock*`

Similar to `OnBlockCreate`. 

### `OnVerifySignature`

The chart shows that BLS and Secp256k1 are indeed different, with both having significant non-zero intercepts at 0 byte input size; actually there's huge deviation in runtime when the input size is zero. Yet the gas price is constant, although that constant depends on the signature type. We have to make it depend on input size as well.

Looking at he overall chart, we can see that the minimum time for BLS is just above the maximum time measured for Secp256k1, yet the price difference between them is 10x, which is unfair.

### `OnRecoverSecpPublicKey`

This operation works on hashes, not plain text, so the runtime doesn't depend on the input size. This is visible on the chart: we generate different input sizes but just so we can see a nice horizontal distribution (ie. the hashing is explicitly happening outside the syscall we measure). 

What's not visible on the chart is whether the actual gas price is adequate or not. This we could only tell if there was a target ratio between time and gas, with which we could divide the gas to compare nanos to nanos.

## Trial on the Conformance Test Vectors

I took the slopes from the regressions and used them in the price model of `on_block_*` method and `on_hashing` to see if the conformance test vectors would show better correlation between time and gas. I left the intercepts alone, because that was often negative, and looking at the charts did not contradict that they intercept the Y axis at zero.

Unfortunately no, it's mostly the same, some R-squared are better, some worse. 

I noticed that for example with `OnBlockCreate`, even on the summed charts that look at the aggregate time spent by a contract doing a given thing is on average 10,000 nanos, which is well in the domain where the observations exhibited diverging costs. That suggests that the contracts are writing so little data that it's not a good predictor of the runtime. 

I also suspected that measuring time using the in-memory blockstore is not a good way to model, but I'm not yet sure how to compensate for that. Maybe we can use a persistent block store, even if in production it's the buffered one; we'll write things eventually, most of the time, I guess.


# Follow up actions
* Deal with memory init in terms of Wasm size in a different PR (and rethink if it should be a different charge)
* Change the gas on the charts into nanos at 10,000milligas/nanos rate. Done in https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/pull/1242
* Try to update the prices based on the regression and see if the overall slopes become better aligned
* Rebase onto master
* Add more charges that appeared there
* Run the same tests on a canonic environment
* Fix the prices based on the canonic regression results

title: refactor: make send take all arguments
body: Remove send_read_only. The goal was to avoid breaking changes, but we needed to break things anyways to thread the gas through.

title: fix: mark "send" params as "raw"
body: A non-controversial part of #987.

title: CHORE-1170: Add license headers
body:
Closes https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/1170

The PR adds a `add_license.sh` file similar to [Forest](https://github.com/ChainSafe/forest/tree/main/scripts) that can be invoked with `make license`, which is also called from CI. The script formats files where necessary and returns an error if it did so, which will stop CI, so we have to go back and commit these changes.

The script does two things:
1. It checks that each Rust code file has a license header. If not, it adds the copyright with _Protocol Labs_. 
2. It checks that every Rust file that changed compared to `master` has _Protocol Labs_ in the header, and adds it if not. At this point the common SPDX part should have already been added by 1), or present from when the file was originally copied from _ChainSafe Systems_. 

The effect should be that any file we modify will force us to add _Protocol Labs_. The ones we don't touch are kept as _ChainSafe_. 

I added _Protocol Labs_ to any file that changed since it has been taken in 5c13b82879c31c8a1e37e320b8a55fc736486e1a as a one-off step.

title: feat: remove the gas limit from the context
body:
We don't actually need this, and users should use `gas::available`.

fixes #1168

title: fix: only push backtrace frames on error.
